The potato/pəˈteɪtoʊ/ is a starchy food, a tuber of the plant Solanum tuberosum and is a root vegetable native to the Americas. The plant is a perennial in the nightshade family Solanaceae.[2]  Wild potato species can be found from the southern United States to southern Chile.[3] The potato was originally believed to have been domesticated (§ History) by Native Americans independently in multiple locations,[4] but later genetic studies traced a single origin, in the area of present-day southern Peru and extreme northwestern Bolivia. Potatoes were domesticated there approximately 7,000–10,000 years ago, from a species in the S. brevicaule complex.[5][6][7] In the Andes region of South America, where the species is indigenous, some close relatives of the potato are cultivated.  Potatoes were introduced to Europe from the Americas by the Spanish in the second half of the 16th century. Today they are a staple food in many parts of the world and an integral part of much of the world's food supply. As of 2014, potatoes were the world's fourth-largest food crop after maize (corn), wheat, and rice.[8] Following millennia of selective breeding, there are now over 5,000 different types of potatoes.[6] Over 99% of potatoes presently cultivated worldwide descend from varieties that originated in the lowlands of south-central Chile.[9] The importance of the potato as a food source and culinary ingredient varies by region and is still changing. It remains an essential crop in Europe, especially Northern and Eastern Europe, where per capita production is still the highest in the world, while the most rapid expansion in production during the 21st century was in southern and eastern Asia, with China and India leading the world production of 376 million tonnes (370,000,000 long tons; 414,000,000 short tons), as of 2021.  Like the tomato, the potato is a nightshade in the genus Solanum, and the vegetative and fruiting parts of the potato contain the toxin solanine which is dangerous for human consumption. Normal potato tubers that have been grown and stored properly produce glycoalkaloids in amounts small enough to be negligible for human health, but, if green sections of the plant (namely sprouts and skins) are exposed to light, the tuber can accumulate a high enough concentration of glycoalkaloids to affect human health.[10]

The kernel is the layer of software between the hardware and the higher level of the operating system (OS). The kernel performs basic low level functions such as accepting a character from the keyboard, displaying a character on the screen, switching between processes, transferring one block of data from memory to a sector on a disk drive, etc. The higher level of the OS performs functions such as sorting data in a file in alphabetical order, compiling program source code, executing compiled code, etc.

well kinda, the IBM systems, MVT MVS OS/390 ....didn't  use API's (at the time) as you stated, high level programs and even low level programs provided macros to open, get and put and print...and other functions, the compiler converted these statements into machine code, the machine code, even in the early days, interfaced with the I/O subsystem and peripheral devices.. simply put, there's more to it, but ah no, no API.  Univac, Cray, Digital, Sun each have their own instruction set to do pretty much the same type of work, each had their niche

The printer at 5:43 displays a carriage tape. It did control form feed, top of form and feed to a predefined position (channel). Oh, those days. I wrote a printer driver in assembler to a really no-brain printer. It had no buffer, so I had to time each character calculating the time needed to change position and feed paper. As a bonus I added a tabulator function.  The printer was a desktop model. It weighed 50 kg or more. My bicycle broke down when I moved this thing home on it.

Windows not supporting protected memory properly throughout the 80's and early 90's was Intel's fault, arguably. The 286 was a bear to work with, when trying to use it's protected memory mode and Bill Gates went so far as to call it "brain dead" and tell people not to buy computers using it.
saw many video trying to grasp the concept of kernel, now I can say done.
Memory protection required hardware/CPU support. MS-DOS ran in non-protected mode, and programs were responsible for entering protected mode and calling back into DOS when needed. It was a mess.

I think she should have mentioned that UNIX is still with us in the form of Linux and Android, it really makes you appreciate the age and amount of work that went into these things. (also BSD and Darwin :) )  To me its astonishing how even after all these years, even if the way we do computing has changed completely, Linux is still very much a multi-user system designed for main frames; you can see it everywhere from user management and the permission system, to the way tasks are handled, the filesystem and the presence of TTYs. The core principles of UNIX are still very much present. Personally i find amazing how stratified, complex and messy Linux is: it never really changed from that original design, it only grew is size and functionality: you can pick up a UNIX manual from the 1980s and find that 90% of the information in there still works with some very minor changes, it blows my mind :D

It is still paging, if the requested memory is not in the virtual address table you get a PAGE_FAULT which transfers control to the operating system, which yes does "swap" the desired page with the least frequently accessed page.
The place it's stored is called the swap, but the feature itself is called paging.

No, Unix was terrible compared to many of its contemporaries as far as features & productivity go. It just happened to run on cheap hardware. Perfect for universities and government run organization, where securing funding for equipment is much harder than securing funding for employee man hours, even if the latter ends up costing more in the long run.

Stallman was not involved in Unix. He is on the recorded as saying it is awful as it is not open source. pro tip: never go full Stallman.
What do you mean "full Stallman?" You're basically saying don't use GNU/GPL.

Stallman is a excellent example of taking a good idea way to far. Stallman says you should only use software that is 100% open. So for example he will not listen to mp3's (mp3 is not a open format). he thinks both ios and android are bad and should not be used. He is absolutely militant about this sort of thing. Going so far as to say that you using Skype is morally wrong because by doing so you are pressuring others to use it to talk with you, and this strips them of their freedom. He is huge in software development and open source, but people have a tendency to over look the radical honestly nonsensical parts of his dogma. The TL;DR is ya he did a lot of important stuff, but he is not some infallible savor figure.
ogg is far better.

BosonCollider Unix provided abstractions other systems of the time didn't. pipe(2) and the io redirection that comes with it, regex tooling, The Unix Philosophy, Everything Is A File, plaintext configuration, and a half-dozen other conventions and ideas whose importance cannot be overstated can be traced to or were popularized by UNIX.  No, UNIX isn't perfect. Plan9 is arguably a cleaner system, and there are a dozen other ideas for better systems out there. But it's better than people tend to give it credit for.  And really, the OS that was going to win in the 70/80s had to be portable, and reasonably close to the metal, can you name a system better than UNIX that has those characteristics? MULTICS? VMS?   As elegant and cool as some of Unix's competitors were, they don't really fill those criteria for the most part. This includes That One System that always gets brought up as the better OS of the time. That System ran on one processor made by one company and had a tiny install base. Massively influential though it may be (having made an indelible mark on programming tooling, culture, and history that lasts to this day), That System was never going to win, and if you think otherwise, you're straight-up delusional.

The only conservative feature of American English that I'm aware of is the rhoticity (what the consonant r sounds like). England has a plethora of accents, but the one people stereotype as "British accent" (shake my head at the gross over-generalisation, since British includes wild-cards like Scottish) is usually the Londonese, south-Eastern variety, and this one uses a modern rhoticity, which the American English variety could boast to out-compete, in terms of conserving the original language. That being said: in every other way that Americans bastardise the language, it's quite upsetting.

There is no British dialect. Great Britain is made up of England, Scotland, and Wales, all of which have different dialects and accents, also depending on where in England/Scotland/Wales you are (e.g. the north of England has a different accent and sort of different dialect to the south). Also, as a person who lives NEAR (not in) London, I pronounce it "sked-joule"
